Package game_code

Class GameStats

java.lang.Object
game_code.GameStats
public class GameStats
extends java.lang.Object
A class that holds most of the game's data and info. Holds things like money, time, the economy and so on.
Author:
nzoli

  • Field Summary

    Fields
    Modifier and Type Field Description

    The amount of money that the player has for paying wages and buying items.
    private java.lang.String name
    The trader's name.
    private int profit
    The profit made by the player, displayed at the end of the game.
    private int time
    The maximum amount of time left in the game.

    The amount of time remaining in the game before it ends.

  • Field Details

    • ECONOMY

      private static java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,​Good> ECONOMY
      The collection of goods that the game runs with. Should not be changed during the course of the game.

    • time

      private int time
      The maximum amount of time left in the game. The player will select this.

    • timeLeft

      private double timeLeft
      The amount of time remaining in the game before it ends.

    • money

      private int money
      The amount of money that the player has for paying wages and buying items. has a default starting amount.

    • name

      private java.lang.String name
      The trader's name. The player should pick this at the start of the game.

    • goodsSold

      private java.util.Hashtable<Good,​java.lang.Integer> goodsSold
      Very similar to the ship's cargo HashTable, but this is used to keep track of what goods have been sold. We must do this, as it is a project requirement. This is private because we only need to either get it, or increase a value. In other words, our needs for this are much more constrained.

    • profit

      private int profit
      The profit made by the player, displayed at the end of the game.

  • Constructor Details

    • GameStats

      public GameStats()
      Constructor for the class. Also makes the economy. Since the economy is static, it only needs to be made once.

  • Method Details

    • createEconomy

      private void createEconomy()
      Creates the game's economy, a collection of Good instances

    • createGoodsSold

      private void createGoodsSold​(java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,​Good> ECONOMY)
      A small redundancy as Ship has the same code. Creates the goodsSold HashSet. I could possibly make a different function that returned the HashTable this generates/modifies But that would complicate the code more than having this duplicate code here.
      Parameters:
      ECONOMY - the economy that the game is working with.

    • recordSale

      public void recordSale​(Good product, int quantity)
      Adds the specified quantity to the amount of that Good sold
      Parameters:
      product - the type of Good that is being sold.
      quantity - How many of it is being sold.

    • getGoodsSold

      public java.util.Hashtable<Good,​java.lang.Integer> getGoodsSold()
      gets the goodsSold hashtable.
      Returns:
      The Hashtable containing the goods sold and how much of them is sold.

    • changeMoney

      public void changeMoney​(int amount)
      Changes the money by the specified amount.
      Parameters:
      amount - Increases money by amount. To reduce money, make this negative.

    • getMoney

      public int getMoney()
      gets the amount of money the player has.
      Returns:
      The player's money, in integer form.

    • getEconomy

      public static java.util.Hashtable<java.lang.String,​Good> getEconomy()
      Gets the economy
      Returns:
      The game's economy, in the form of a HashSet containing 'Good' instances

    • getGood

      public static Good getGood​(java.lang.String name)
      Gets a specific Good instance, for access, from the game's economy.
      Parameters:
      name - The name of the good. And must be a string.
      Returns:
      The desired Good instance.

    • getTime

      public int getTime()
      Gets the time - specifically the max amount of days in the game
      Returns:
      The max numbers of days in the game. In integer form.

    • getTimeLeft

      public double getTimeLeft()
      Gets how much time the game has left before it ends.
      Returns:
      The number of days left in the game before it ends. In double form.

    • setTime

      public void setTime​(int days)
      Sets the maximum amount of time for the game. Also sets the timeLeft to the same value. Should only be used once - during the start of a game.
      Parameters:
      days - The maximum number of days in the game.

    • setTimeLeft

      private void setTimeLeft​(double days)
      Sets the time left before the game ends to the given double. Should not be used to change the time - use advanceTime instead.
      Parameters:
      days - The number of days left before the game ends.

    • advanceTime

      public void advanceTime​(double days)
      reduces timeLeft by the given amount. So a positive value indicates that days have passed. A negative value indicates time is flowing backwards.
      Parameters:
      days - The number of days that have passed.

    • getName

      public java.lang.String getName()
      gets the trader's name
      Returns:
      name The trader's name. In string form.

    • getProfit

      public int getProfit()
      gets the profit made by the player
      Returns:
      profit The profit made by the player, in int form.

    • setname

      public void setname​(java.lang.String text) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
      Sets the name of the trader. Should only be done at the start of the game. See characterCheck for valid name conditions.
      Parameters:
      text - The name of the trader-to-be. Should be a string.
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - Is thrown if the name is not valid.

    • characterCheck

      public static void characterCheck​(java.lang.String text) throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
      Checks the string to see if all of its characters are valid. Only accepts names of 3 to 15 characters in length (inclusive), containing only the characters a-z, A-Z, and the whitespace. Two consecutive whitespaces are not allowed, however. Does nothing if it is valid. if invalid, throws an illegal argument exception.
      Parameters:
      text - The string that is being checked for validity.
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - This is thrown if the string is the wrong length or contains illegal characters
